channel.title: Elias Judin
channel.description: Elias Judin's academic website and mathematics research blog on category theory, universal algebra, topology, and sheaf theory.

item.title: Topological, Lax-Topological (Semi-Topological/Solid), and Topologically Algebraic Functors
item.description: Notes on topological, lax-topological (semi-topological/solid), and topologically algebraic functors via structured sources/sinks, classical characterizations, and the quantaloid-enriched “topological = total” theorem.

item.title: Curriculum Vitae
item.description: Academic CV of Elias Judin, M.Sc. Mathematics student (UCT). Details education (Wits B.Sc., UCT Hons), teaching experience, awards, summer schools, and focus on pure mathematics.

item.title: Log
item.description:
January 2025

I was watching one of Scholze’s talks on Condensed Mathematics(which I hadn’t been exposed to before). This is how I understood it. Scholze is basically fixing that Top\mathsf{Top} is bad for algebra by switching to a setting where descent actually works. He complains that quotients in Top are “violent" and destroy algebraic structure (like how topological abelian groups aren’t an abelian category) but I think he’s just pointing out that topological quotients aren’t effective descent morphisms for ’nice’ algebraic structures. Scholze replaces spaces with sheaves on profinite sets (making them projective generators), which seems to be exactly how you force the covers he wants to become effective for descent. Notably, while Top\mathsf{Top} works fine as a topological category (meaning it admits initial liftings of structured sources, which implies completeness/cocompleteness), it fails to be an exact category because those quotients aren’t effective (specifically, it is not Barr-exact).

item.title: Reflections on the Right Use of Artificial Intelligence With a View to the Love of Mathematics
item.description: Speculative essay on Meillassoux’s arche-fossil, Simone Weil’s attention, and whether AI-generated mathematics could signal an ancestral truth that exists beyond human understanding while still demanding translation back into meaning for us.

item.title: Tarski's automorphisms
item.description: Notes on Alfred Tarski’s 1966 lecture “What are logical notions?” and his proposal that logical notions are precisely those invariant under all automorphisms of the universe of discourse, with references for further reading.

item.title: Sheaves as Presheaves with an Equalizer Diagram
item.description: Short primer explaining presheaves, the locality and gluing axioms, and the equalizer diagram that packages the sheaf condition for a topological space.

item.title: Monomorphisms and epimorphisms
item.description: Lecture-style notes on monomorphisms and epimorphisms: closure under composition, split morphisms, and how Choice makes Set epis split, with examples.

item.title: hom-Sets
item.description: Hom-sets worked out in any category: hom-functors preserve identities and composition, and detect monos/epis by injectivity - notes for Lean 4 formalisation.

item.title: Describing difficult spaces
item.description: A guide to describing and visualizing complex topological spaces such as tori, Klein bottles, and Möbius strips using gluing diagrams and geometric intuition. Explores identification spaces.

item.title: Free semimodules and their examples
item.description: Honours project on free semimodules and their examples. Covers definitions, universal properties, and connections to category theory and universal algebra. Supervised by Prof. G. Janelidze (UCT).

item.title: M-sets and Yoneda for monoids
item.description: Yoneda lemma for monoids via M-sets: explicit Nat(M(-), X) <-> X bijection, Cayley as a corollary, plus Yoneda embedding and an enriched remark for self-study.

item.title: Free algebras by means of a universal property
item.description: Free algebras as initial objects in C[X]. Example: free vector spaces; the universal-property definition also yields free magmas, free groups, and more.

item.title: Modules and Vector Spaces as Algebraic Categories
item.description: Exercises in category theory: how modules over a ring and vector spaces over a field can be framed as algebraic categories by extending the operator signatures to handle scalar multiplication.

item.title: Groupoids and skeletons of monoids and preorders
item.description: Monoids and preorders as categories: characterize when they are groupoids (groups/equivalence relations) and when they are skeletons (orders). With examples.

item.title: Exercises in category theory
item.description: Series of posts containing short answers to exercises in category theory from my honours year at the University of Cape Town

item.title: Is the Double Twisted Möbius Strip Isotopic to the Strip?
item.description: Using Tokieda’s overflow heuristic and isotopy in R^3, show the double-twisted Mobius strip cannot isotope to the ordinary strip (Hopf link obstruction).

item.description: How to reach Elias Judin for research collaborations, speaking invitations, or encrypted correspondence, plus links to GitHub and LinkedIn profiles.
